All this antique furniture left by your grandfather, you bet it probably looked somewhat presentable when he had it, but it didn't go with anything in your parents' house, so off it went into the attic, forgotten. This may very well be an archaeological find, judging by how old some of these items look. You open the round window at the front end of the attic so you don't suffocate in the stale air up here.

"Shit," you mutter, hoping your mom didn't hear that. As you bend over to pick up the pieces, you notice something gleam off the beam of your flashlight. Something very strange-looking indeed. You reach under the vanity and pull it out to inspect it.

It's a sizeable knife, probably the most beautiful one you've ever seen. The first thing you notice as you gently swing it around is how incredibly light it is. The pommel has the brightest gem you've ever seen, the magenta-tinted stone catching your flashlight and making it dance like a kaleidoscope on the floor and wall in front of you. The onyx-colored blade is firm, razor sharp, and delicately curved ending in an incredibly fine point. This looks more like a priceless work of art than a knife. You not only have no idea how it got in that vase, but also how it's stayed in such pristine condition when everything else in here looks like it would crumble if you breathed on it wrong.

You place the knife on top of the rickety old vanity and continue your inventory of the attic. There's, what, three armoires up here? Who even needs that many bulky, ugly closets? You walk over to the dustiest one and brush off a few cobwebs. Slowly, you pry it open, the ancient door creaking to reveal nothing but a couple old coats. They're wrapped in plastic, but somehow the super-powered moths living in your attic have managed to get through them and devour significant portions of them anyway. You push them aside to reveal...

"FUCK!!"

A bat, cranky from having its beauty sleep interrupted, takes flight in the direction of your face! You scream and stumble back, tumbling over the vanity and falling to the floor. It breaks with a crunch and you hear the knife clatter on the floorboards. You shelter in place, putting your hand over your head as the bat circles the room. Eventually, it finds the open window and makes its exit. You get up quickly and rush to shut the window so it can't get back in.

"Phew..." you gasp as you wipe the sweat from your brow with your wrist. Wait...

Wasn't there a hand here a minute ago?

You look down wide-eyed at your right arm to see that it ends in a perfectly smooth stump of flesh. It looks like you never had a hand. You'd scream again if it weren't for the shock. Out of the corner of your eye, you spot something moving on the floor by the rubble of the vanity.

"It... couldn't be..."

But it could.

You give yourself a thumbs up, again all systems go. You bend over and pick up your hand, noting how strange it feels to be holding it like this. As you look it over you notice no significant damage other than a couple minor scuffs from landing hard on the floor. It also ends in the exact same stump your right wrist does.

Putting two and two together, you try to put hand and wrist together. Thankfully, two and two add up to four. Your hand is securely attached back on your wrist. No amount of tugging seems to pop it back off.

"How the hell did that happen?" you ask yourself, until you notice the gemstone-encrusted pommel of the knife poking out from the rubble of the destroyed vanity. You brush the wood aside and retrieve the blade. It's still in immaculate condition. There's only one explanation as to what could have happened to your hand, but it's just... insane... right? Right!? Your heart flutters as you decide to take the ultimate leap of faith.

"Here goes nothing..." you say as you tightly shut your eyes and grip the knife, swinging it down quickly. You don't even hear a chop, you just hear and feel a thud. When you open your eyes, your left hand is resting on the ground, again, no blood or pain. You bend over and pick this one up too, examining it. After you're sufficiently sure what you're seeing is real, you put it back on and wiggle your fingers, testing them. Everything continues to be all good.

"This is going to be fun. Weird, but fun," you say, forgetting all about cleaning the attic. But, who should you talk to first about the knife?
